Generating Reports

Source: vignettes/docs/reporting.Rmd
reporting.Rmd

Multiple Experiments

Often researchers need to annotate multiple signatures across multiple experiments. Typically, the best way to manage this data is to process it all at once and generate a markdown report to analyze and share with collaborators.

hypdat <- readRDS(file.path(system.file("extdata", package="hypeR"), "hypdat.rds"))

In the following example, we’re interested in exploring the signatures from a Weighted Gene Co-expression Analysis of two different phenotypes. In hypdat, we take the resulting co-expression modules from WGCNA ran separately on gene expression data from carcinogenic and non-carcinogenic compounds. There are 15 modules of co-expressed genes for carcinogenic compounds and 16 modules of co-expressed genes for non-carcinogenic compounds. Using hyp_to_rmd() will help us process this data in a concise and reproducible manner that is readily shareable.

signatures <- hypdat$wgcna
str(signatures)
List of 2
 $ NON-CARC  :List of 16
  ..$ M0 : chr [1:1490] "C9orf156" "GRIN3A" "HES3" "HTR1B" ...
  ..$ M1 : chr [1:1852] "OPRK1" "AVP" "NEURL2" "STOX2" ...
  ..$ M2 : chr [1:1390] "ZBTB2" "ADPRHL2" "UQCR11" "UNK" ...
  ..$ M3 : chr [1:559] "RALY" "MED11" "MANBAL" "PM20D2" ...
  ..$ M4 : chr [1:1309] "C1QTNF7" "CYP4F12" "SOCS2" "PRSS2" ...
  ..$ M5 : chr [1:408] "MCUR1" "SOS2" "UBR5" "H3F3B" ...
  ..$ M6 : chr [1:447] "MT-ND2" "MT-ND1" "AQP8" "MT-ND3" ...
  ..$ M9 : chr [1:420] "MPLKIP" "SLC22A7" "CFD" "GYPC" ...

  ..$ M13: chr [1:516] "CMPK2" "S100A16" "PTPRO" "H3F3B" ...
  ..$ M15: chr [1:185] "SPIC" "SLFN11" "ARHGDIB" "CYBB" ...

  ..$ M19: chr [1:141] "SOCS2" "HSDL2" "CBLB" "CMTM8" ...
  ..$ M23: chr [1:89] "INPP5A" "SEZ6L2" "C9orf172" "KIF5B" ...

Because we have a nested list of signatures, we use hyper() with the lapply function. This results in a list of multihyp objects, which can be directly passed to hyp_to_rmd().

genesets <- hyperdb_rgsets("REACTOME", "70.0")

lmultihyp_obj <- lapply(signatures, hypeR, genesets, test="hypergeometric", background=50000, fdr=0.01)

Generating Markdown Reports

hyp_to_rmd() will accept multiple formats, including a single hyp or multihyp object as well as a list of either, including a list of hyp or multihyp objects together.

When a list of multihyp objects are passed for example, each experiment will become its own section, while each signature becomes its own tab within that section.

Lists of keyword arguments can be passed for hyp_dots(), hyp_emap(), and hyp_hmap(), allowing customization of their functionality per report. See hyp_to_rmd() for details.

hyp_to_rmd(lmultihyp_obj,
           file_path="hypeR.rmd",
           title="hypeR Report",
           subtitle="Weighted Gene Co-expression Analysis",
           author="Anthony Federico, Stefano Monti",
           show_dots=T,
           show_emaps=T,
           show_hmaps=T,
           show_tables=T)

An example of these types of reports can be viewed at https://montilab.github.io/hypeR-reporting.

Developed by Anthony Federico, Stefano Monti.

Site built with pkgdown 1.4.1.
